lines.speaker: u2102
lines.text: I'm gonna lose you, Charlie.

lines.speaker: u2105
lines.text: It'll all be over tomorrow. No more wars. No more killin'. Just livin' normal like everybody else.  You'll be stuck with me for good.

lines.speaker: u2103
lines.text: Julius Caesar never took no vote.

lines.speaker: u2105
lines.text: And maybe that's why he ended up dead in the streets of Rome.

lines.speaker: u2104
lines.text: We're gonna change it, Bugs. Once we get rid of the Dons, the Commission's gonna rule. No more wars. No more vendettas. No more Boss of All the Bosses.

lines.speaker: u2112
lines.text: Yeah. And no more Tommy Reina.

lines.speaker: u2112
lines.text: I'm a hard guy. I done more jobs than alla you combined. And I never said no. Not once. But dammit I don't understand why the hell we gotta kill our friends!

lines.speaker: u2105
lines.text: Because the world ain't big enough for the Dons. So we gotta choose between our friends and ourselves. It ain't the way I'd make the world, but that's the way it is.

lines.speaker: u2106
lines.text: What a cozy little scene.

lines.speaker: u2108
lines.text: Kill them! Kill them!

lines.speaker: u2106
lines.text: What's it worth to ya, Boss?

lines.speaker: u2108
lines.text: Anything!

lines.speaker: u2106
lines.text: Anything ain't a very hard number.

lines.speaker: u2108
lines.text: One hundred thousand. No... three hundred thousand.

lines.speaker: u2106
lines.text: Now that's a hard number.

lines.speaker: u2110
lines.text: You're fuckin' crazy.

lines.speaker: u2112
lines.text: But only on purpose, Tommy.

lines.speaker: u2110
lines.text: This is nice. I mean it.

lines.speaker: u2120
lines.text: "4/17: Subject, when unaware of observation, prefers to hold eating utensils...with feet. Successfully carves turkey roll holding eating utensils...with feet."

lines.speaker: u2113
lines.text: They had a case like that at Johns Hopkins. Wires got crossed between hands and feet.

lines.speaker: u2114
lines.text: Hey, Stu, why so glum? Everybody loves a good humiliation nightmare.

lines.speaker: u2124
lines.text: Three months, Bull. Three months tonight. Three months since the accident - and I'm no closer to going home than I was then.

lines.speaker: u2114
lines.text: Aw, buck up. Have another 'tini.

lines.speaker: u2124
lines.text: I'm sick of martinis. I'm sick of the waiting, and the carnival rides, and watching people's <u>nightmares</u>. And of course, I need not <u>add</u> -

lines.speaker: u2124
lines.text: Hey. Where's Monkeybone?

lines.speaker: u2115
lines.text: Back in your head, where he belongs. No offense, Stu, but on your own you're kinda vanilla. I didn't want to send you back without him.

lines.speaker: u2124
lines.text: Back? You're sending me back?

lines.speaker: u2115
lines.text: It's irregular, but...I just love that strip of yours. I figure I'll take the "Family Circus" guy instead.

lines.speaker: u2124
lines.text: Death! Thank you!

lines.speaker: u2115
lines.text: Thank me next time you see me.

lines.speaker: u2116
lines.text: Three months. There's always some brain damage. But at three months...the chances of coming back shrink dramatically with every day.

lines.speaker: u2121
lines.text: I want him to have every chance, Doctor. We can certainly give it...three months.

lines.speaker: u2124
lines.text: So here's my idea. We do a giveaway at the zoo benefit. We get a big pi챰ata. We fill it with Monkeybone dolls - <u>hundreds</u> of 'em.

lines.speaker: u2117
lines.text: A pi챰ata. That's a <u>great</u> idea!

lines.speaker: u2118
lines.text: The Nightmare Juice! It's gone! Somebody switched it for a beaker of grape Kool-Aid!!

lines.speaker: u2120
lines.text: Kool-Aid!? But who'd would want to -

lines.speaker: u2119
lines.text: Easy, pal! I was coming to congratulate you. It ain't easy snatching one of those E-tickets. Steve here was the last guy to pull it off, and that musta been, what, 25 years ago...?

lines.speaker: u2124
lines.text: Why'd you do it? What'd I ever do to you?!?

lines.speaker: u2119
lines.text: It's simple, Stu. We need nightmares - lots of 'em. So whenever we can swing it, we send a guy up to stimulate the flow...a <u>nightmare maker</u>! Like Steve here. Poe. Rasputin...we've been doing this all the way back to Atilla and Genghis Khan!

lines.speaker: u2124
lines.text: But <u>why me</u>? Why'd you pick on <u>me</u>??

lines.speaker: u2119
lines.text: The monkey, of course. It was his idea.

lines.speaker: u2124
lines.text: Monkeybone...!?

lines.speaker: u2119
lines.text: Nobody wants to be a sidekick, Stu. So one day he comes to us - he's got a proposition. We help him get your body...in return he gives us all the nightmares we want.

lines.speaker: u2124
lines.text: You're nuts! I'm a comic strip artist! What's he gonna do - draw <u>really scary cartoons</u>??

lines.speaker: u2119
lines.text: Oh, no, no, no. Y'see, Stu, as it happens, that girlfriend of yours figured out the chemical basis of bad dreams. And she just whipped up a big old batch of nightmare juice!

lines.speaker: u2120
lines.text: Kimmy! What's the matter?

lines.speaker: u2121
lines.text: This is hard for me, Julie...very hard...but it's been three months now, and... I gave the order.

lines.speaker: u2122
lines.text: Go. Just <u>go</u>.

lines.speaker: u2124
lines.text: Thanks, Kitty, I'll never forget you for th--

lines.speaker: u2123
lines.text: Awwww. Worried about my feelings, are you? Well, there's a new twist.

lines.speaker: u2124
lines.text: Don't joke around, little buddy. I mean it. I really do love y--

lines.speaker: u2126
lines.text: Is there something else I can do for you?

lines.speaker: u2127
lines.text: Well, I'd love to see inside your club.

lines.speaker: u2126
lines.text: You want to come inside?

lines.speaker: u2127
lines.text: Well, if you're not holding a meeting or anything.

lines.speaker: u2127
lines.text: I see.  How much?

lines.speaker: u2129
lines.text: Forty-five all total.

lines.speaker: u2127
lines.text: Forty-five?  I thought it was only supposed to be thirty?

lines.speaker: u2129
lines.text: Thirty is base price.  Tolls, tax, tip ... it all adds up.

lines.speaker: u2131
lines.text: Here you are, Senator. Not a bad desk, either. Daniel Webster used to use it.

lines.speaker: u2138
lines.text: Daniel Webster? Sat here? Say--that man was a great orator.

lines.speaker: u2131
lines.text: Give you something to shoot at, Senator--if you figure on doing any talking.

lines.speaker: u2138
lines.text: Not me, sonny. I'm just going to sit around and listen.  What's this?

lines.speaker: u2131
lines.text: Calendar for the day. You'll find the Senate Manual in the drawer. Anything else you want, just snap for a page.

lines.speaker: u2138
lines.text: Where's the Majority Leader?

lines.speaker: u2131
lines.text: The Majority Leader? Right over there. And that's [           ] the Minority Leader. They're both pretty good in the clinches.

lines.speaker: u2138
lines.text: Uh-huh. And where's the Press Galery?

lines.speaker: u2131
lines.text: Right up there over the Vice- President's chair--the four in the front row represent the four big news services. You've met the press bunch, haven't you?

lines.speaker: u2138
lines.text: Oh, yes--they're fine people--regular people.

lines.speaker: u2131
lines.text: Look out for those fellows--they tell the truth about you--sometimes. That corner over there is reserved for guides and sightseers who come in for five minutes to rest their feet. That section over there is reserved for Senator's friends. The front row--the empty one--is for the President and White House guests-- see that old couple over there-- they've attended every session for the last twenty years. Over the clock back here is the Diplomatic section. They and the page boys are the only real class we have in this place. The rest are mostly people who come here like they go to the zoo--

lines.speaker: u2138
lines.text: Those busts up there--all around the wall--who are they, sonny?

lines.speaker: u2131
lines.text: All the ex-vice-Presidents. You can get ten-to-one around here if you think you can remember their names. The Vice-President presides over the Senate--you know that. It's how he earns his pay. Oh--over there, Senator-- on the east side of the Chair we still have the old snuff boxes with real snuff in them if you like snuff.

lines.speaker: u2138
lines.text: Thanks very much, sonny--

lines.speaker: u2131
lines.text: I'll take your hat into the cloak room.

lines.speaker: u2138
lines.text: Here--let me give you a Boy Ranger button.

lines.speaker: u2131
lines.text: Swell. Thanks very much.  Good luck, Senator. Keep your left up.

lines.speaker: u2132
lines.text: And you say you never signed this contract with Mr. Allen?

lines.speaker: u2138
lines.text: I did not--

lines.speaker: u2132
lines.text: You've never *seen* this contract.

lines.speaker: u2138
lines.text: Never.

lines.speaker: u2132
lines.text: But you did *talk* to Mr. Allen about that and--?

lines.speaker: u2138
lines.text: I--I discussed it with him--yes-- because I--you see, I've always had this camp in mind--but I made no contract with him!

lines.speaker: u2132
lines.text: Then--this is *not* you signature, Senator?

lines.speaker: u2138
lines.text: Looks like it, but--

lines.speaker: u2132
lines.text: But it *isn't*?

lines.speaker: u2138
lines.text: It couldn't be.

lines.speaker: u2132
lines.text: You are saying, in effect, that this is a forgery?

lines.speaker: u2138
lines.text: I'm saying I didn't sign it!

lines.speaker: u2141
lines.text: And while you're at it, get me a bed!

lines.speaker: u2133
lines.text: Let's send out a pigeon!

lines.speaker: u2141
lines.text: Blow a bugle!

lines.speaker: u2147
lines.text: Diz!

lines.speaker: u2134
lines.text: Kid--he thinks he's talking to that mob at home, but not a line we've written--not a word he's said from that floor has gotten into that home State.

lines.speaker: u2147
lines.text: What!

lines.speaker: u2134
lines.text: Not a word! Taylor's sewed up every paper. They're tossing out everything that comes in over the wires!

lines.speaker: u2147
lines.text: Freedom of the press! Mr. James Taylor blindfolding a whole State--  Wait a minute! If that's how he wants to play *I'll* get through to that bunch--I'll get plenty of words into that, State--!  Come on, Diz, get that stuff you've written--let me have it--

lines.speaker: u2137
lines.text: Emma! I'm a man at the end of his rope.

lines.speaker: u2135
lines.text: No wonder--without your dinner.

lines.speaker: u2137
lines.text: Emma, which is it--Horace Miller or Henry Hill?

lines.speaker: u2135
lines.text: Well, your children are very bright-- and *they* say Jefferson Smith.

lines.speaker: u2144
lines.text: Are you ready for him, Bill?

lines.speaker: u2136
lines.text: All set. Foley's rooms in the Senate office building--nice, big clean desk--lot of Senator stationery to write his little boys on--and Foley's secretary, Saunders, to make it look like the real thing--

lines.speaker: u2144
lines.text: Good. Are the newspaper men at the hotel?

lines.speaker: u2136
lines.text: Yup--Sweeney, Flood, Farrell--waiting for you--

lines.speaker: u2144
lines.text: Fine. The first thing to do is-- present Mr. Smith to the press--in the *right* way. Hurry him along, Bill.

lines.speaker: u2136
lines.text: How do you feel, champ?

lines.speaker: u2144
lines.text: All right, why?

lines.speaker: u2136
lines.text: Your name's spreading like wild-fire out here--you are the winterbook favorite to get on the National ticket.

lines.speaker: u2144
lines.text: Oh! Go away.

lines.speaker: u2139
lines.text: When Jeff gets through with Taylor, Pop--

lines.speaker: u2137
lines.text: When Jeff gets through with Taylor--  Quiet! What do you mean by breaking in here--? Get out! Get *out* of here!

lines.speaker: u2142
lines.text: Yeah! How about it? You're a nature lover. Do you handle any of that sign language?

lines.speaker: u2138
lines.text: Well--I can *manage*--

lines.speaker: u2141
lines.text: Your Ranger's on the garbage pile, Happy! He's done for!

lines.speaker: u2144
lines.text: Shut up! You've *got* the man pilloried! Do you have to dance around him like a cannibal--!

lines.speaker: u2147
lines.text: Look, Nosey--your pals would like to get in on this, wouldn't they?

lines.speaker: u2142
lines.text: Hey--I wanna *scoop*!

lines.speaker: u2147
lines.text: Well, that's out. Either it's *lots* of reporters and *lots* of tickets or--. Now will you go and call 'em before I change my mind about the whole thing!

lines.speaker: u2142
lines.text: Okay. See you here.

lines.speaker: u2146
lines.text: Is there objection?  You may proceed, Senator.

lines.speaker: u2144
lines.text: Page boys!

lines.speaker: u2153
lines.text: Put that away, slug!  At your service!

lines.speaker: u2173
lines.text: I got a trunk in that room. Will you get it out for me?

lines.speaker: u2153
lines.text: Certainly.

lines.speaker: u2162
lines.text: We'd like to get in touch with him. It's very important.

lines.speaker: u2154
lines.text: Who's that?

lines.speaker: u2162
lines.text: Deeds! Who do you think I'm talking about?

lines.speaker: u2154
lines.text: Oh, yes - Deeds. Fine fellow. Very democratic. You won't have no trouble at all. Talk to anybody.

lines.speaker: u2171
lines.text: He's still pixilated.

lines.speaker: u2155
lines.text: He sure is.

lines.speaker: u2173
lines.text: Are you married?

lines.speaker: u2156
lines.text: Yes, sir.

lines.speaker: u2173
lines.text: Any children?

lines.speaker: u2156
lines.text: No, no children.

lines.speaker: u2173
lines.text: All right, Mr. Dodsworth. I think you'll qualify.  Take this to that desk over there for further instructions.

lines.speaker: u2156
lines.text: Thank you very much.

lines.speaker: u2173
lines.text: Next, please.

lines.speaker: u2176
lines.text: It's for you. In a couple weeks you'll get the itch so bad, you'll be working for nothing.

lines.speaker: u2157
lines.text: Hello . . .

lines.speaker: u2168
lines.text: Ow! My foot's asleep!

lines.speaker: u2158
lines.text: Come on - let's go!

lines.speaker: u2159
lines.text: don't want to be critical, John, but here it is혰

lines.speaker: u2162
lines.text: Yes, I know. A week's gone by and we haven't got the Power of Attorney yet!

lines.speaker: u2159
lines.text: Yes, but you said혰

lines.speaker: u2162
lines.text: I don't care what I said. I can't strangle him, can I!

lines.speaker: u2160
lines.text: How is this, sir?

lines.speaker: u2173
lines.text: Perfect! Perfect!

lines.speaker: u2160
lines.text: I wish you luck, sir.

lines.speaker: u2173
lines.text: Thank you. Now don't touch a thing. Leave everything as it is.

lines.speaker: u2161
lines.text: You can't come up here!

lines.speaker: u2166
lines.text: Let me go! I wanna see him!

lines.speaker: u2161
lines.text: He's not home, I tell you!

lines.speaker: u2166
lines.text: I wanna see that guy!

lines.speaker: u2161
lines.text: We'll send for the police!

lines.speaker: u2166
lines.text: Let me go!

lines.speaker: u2178
lines.text: Come in, please. Come in. Can I get you a cup of tea?

lines.speaker: u2162
lines.text: No, thanks.

lines.speaker: u2178
lines.text: Sit down. Sure I couldn't get you a glass of lemonade or something?

lines.speaker: u2162
lines.text: That's very kind of you. Are you related to him?

lines.speaker: u2178
lines.text: No, I'm his housekeeper.

lines.speaker: u2162
lines.text: Well, we'd like to find out something about him. What does he do for a living?

lines.speaker: u2178
lines.text: He and Jim Mason own the Tallow Works. But that's not where he makes his money. He makes most of it from his poetry.

lines.speaker: u2173
lines.text: Cobb! Get lunch for the rest of them.

lines.speaker: u2163
lines.text: What? There must be 2000 of them out there.

lines.speaker: u2173
lines.text: Well, that doesn't make 'em any less hungry.

lines.speaker: u2163
lines.text: Okay, Santa Claus. 2000 lunches.

lines.speaker: u2173
lines.text: Now, where were we?

lines.speaker: u2164
lines.text: You see, Mr. Deeds, the opera is not conducted like any ordinary business.

lines.speaker: u2173
lines.text: Why not?

lines.speaker: u2164
lines.text: Because it just isn't a business, that's all!

lines.speaker: u2173
lines.text: Well, maybe it isn't to you, but it certainly is a business to me, if I have to make up a loss of $180,000. If it's losing that much money, there must be something wrong. Maybe you charge too much. Maybe you're selling bad merchandise. Maybe lots of things. I don't know. You see, I expect to do a lot of good with that money. And I can't afford to put it into anything that I don't look into. That's my decision for the time being, gentlemen. Goodbye, and thank you for making me Chairman.

lines.speaker: u2181
lines.text: You remember, Dr. Fosdick, in my last book there are some very fine examples.

lines.speaker: u2165
lines.text: Uh-huh.

lines.speaker: u2181
lines.text: Especially, the one of the young nobleman, you remember?

lines.speaker: u2165
lines.text: Oh, yes. Yes, of course Dr. Von Holler. Very interesting.

lines.speaker: u2181
lines.text: It reminds me very much of this one. Nicht wahr?

lines.speaker: u2165
lines.text: Ja.

lines.speaker: u2181
lines.text: It takes so long to detect them혰  혰because their mood changes so often and so quickly. Now, Your Honor, may I show you? May I use the chart?

lines.speaker: u2166
lines.text: 혰my wife wanted me to tell you she혰  혰she prays for you every night.

lines.speaker: u2173
lines.text: Well, thanks, I - uh혰  How do you do? What is your name?

lines.speaker: u2173
lines.text: There's one nice thing about being rich - you ring a bell and things happen. When the servant comes in, Mr. Hallor, I'm going to ask him to show you to the door. Many people don't know where it is.

lines.speaker: u2169
lines.text: No use in getting tough. That'll get you nowhere, Mr. Deeds.  You know, we've got letters.

lines.speaker: u2170
lines.text: Look, he's temperamental.

lines.speaker: u2173
lines.text: Yeah, what if I am? What about it?

lines.speaker: u2172
lines.text: Anything else, Mr. Deeds?

lines.speaker: u2173
lines.text: No.  Yes. There's just one more thing I'd like to get off my chest before I finish.

lines.speaker: u2172
lines.text: Proceed.

lines.speaker: u2173
lines.text: Thank you, Your Honor.

lines.speaker: u2183
lines.text: Shall I call the police, sir?

lines.speaker: u2173
lines.text: No!  What do you want!!

lines.speaker: u2196
lines.text: You can go out there if you like...

lines.speaker: u2184
lines.text: "There's no shame in getting a little therapy", right, Doc?

lines.speaker: u2185
lines.text: Her friend from the city came and took her out to dinner. First time in a long time she's been willing.

lines.speaker: u2196
lines.text: A friend?

lines.speaker: u2186
lines.text: Better make yourself comfortable. We got a three hour drive here.

lines.speaker: u2196
lines.text: I'm fine.

lines.speaker: u2186
lines.text: You're the shrink, aren't you?

lines.speaker: u2196
lines.text: No, not really.

lines.speaker: u2186
lines.text: But you do therapy?

lines.speaker: u2196
lines.text: Not any more.

lines.speaker: u2196
lines.text: I see.

lines.speaker: u2187
lines.text: And please, for whatever small way I may have encouraged this, accept my apologies.  There is good news, though.

lines.speaker: u2196
lines.text: What's that?

lines.speaker: u2187
lines.text: Phyllis has decided to leave town and pursue her practice in the city. Which leaves you the only psychologist in town.

lines.speaker: u2196
lines.text: Dr. Sheeler is leaving Mumford? I'm sorry to hear that.

lines.speaker: u2187
lines.text: As you can imagine, my own feelings about this are mixed... Unlike, I must say, those of my wife.

lines.speaker: u2196
lines.text: I feel like we're making real progress here.

lines.speaker: u2188
lines.text: Me too, Doc. And I can't tell you what that package meant to me --

lines.speaker: u2196
lines.text: What brought this on?

lines.speaker: u2189
lines.text: I'm not at liberty to say. Sometimes it's just routine, sometimes there's been a complaint. We'll be in touch.

lines.speaker: u2190
lines.text: You're the doctor, what do you think?

lines.speaker: u2196
lines.text: She seems very unhappy.

lines.speaker: u2191
lines.text: Mr. White, I am frustrated that the criminal code in this state allows a maximum sentence of only six months and a maximum fine of only $2000.

lines.speaker: u2196
lines.text: I'm sorry, your honor.

lines.speaker: u2191
lines.text: What?

lines.speaker: u2196
lines.text: I'm sorry you're frustrated.

lines.speaker: u2191
lines.text: Are you disrespecting this court, Mr. White?

lines.speaker: u2196
lines.text: No, sir. I was empathizing. Sorry.

lines.speaker: u2191
lines.text: Maybe you can empathize with this -- Maximum fine. Three months in jail, three months house arrest. Sentence to begin immediately at the Orchard Valley Correctional Facility. Case closed. This court is adjourned.

lines.speaker: u2196
lines.text: What it might take is... doing time.

lines.speaker: u2192
lines.text: Too bad. That's tough, I mean it. I'm not unsympathetic. But Skip says you're in love.

lines.speaker: u2193
lines.text: It's a country club. Don't worry about it.

lines.speaker: u2196
lines.text: Thanks for your help, Lionel.

lines.speaker: u2196
lines.text: How are you?

lines.speaker: u2194
lines.text: Insane! Didn't ja hear? My family got five hundred times better.  Let's go, Vanessa.

lines.speaker: u2195
lines.text: Sofie. It's so obvious... you're after my daughter.

lines.speaker: u2196
lines.text: Well, I gotta say, Mrs. Cook, you're right about that.

lines.speaker: u2198
lines.text: Yes... your particular approach.

lines.speaker: u2196
lines.text: I don't have one really. Most of the time I'm faking it. See, I think there's not much that can be done about most problems... they're too complicated, too deep-rooted by the time I hear about them. The most I can do, usually, is look and listen real closely, try to catch some glimpse of the secret life everybody's got. If I can get a sense of that, well then, maybe... just maybe, I can help them out a little.

lines.speaker: u2201
lines.text: If he arrives before us, it will be too late.

lines.speaker: u2208
lines.text: Did you say 'kill' my sister?

lines.speaker: u2202
lines.text: ...and how do you say? Those slimy things, in your stomach?

lines.speaker: u2205
lines.text: Intestines.

lines.speaker: u2202
lines.text: Yeah! Them.

lines.speaker: u2203
lines.text: Which would be located not far to the east of the Anubis statue.

lines.speaker: u2209
lines.text: Don't tell me we gotta go back out there?

lines.speaker: u2203
lines.text: If we want to kill the creature, yes.

lines.speaker: u2204
lines.text: The hell with this. I'm goin, downstairs to get me a drink. You want somethin'?

lines.speaker: u2206
lines.text: Yeah, get me a glass of bourbon, a shot of bourbon and a bourbon chaser.

lines.speaker: u2205
lines.text: Ah! Ah! Ahmenophus!

lines.speaker: u2208
lines.text: Yes,... I see.

lines.speaker: u2209
lines.text: Do something, Jonathan! Kill it!

lines.speaker: u2208
lines.text: You have got to be joking?

lines.speaker: u2211
lines.text: And I know the terrible revenge that you plan to inflict on this city.

lines.speaker: u2214
lines.text: I guess you know just about everything, don't you, Lance?

lines.speaker: u2211
lines.text: Um-hmm.

lines.speaker: u2214
lines.text: Except for one little thing.

lines.speaker: u2211
lines.text: And what's that?

lines.speaker: u2214
lines.text: That I've hot wired the city's entire power supply through that catwalk.

lines.speaker: u2211
lines.text: What --?

lines.speaker: u2212
lines.text: You two timing psychotic bastard.

lines.speaker: u2214
lines.text: Darling, you've got the wrong idea.

lines.speaker: u2212
lines.text: Do I?

lines.speaker: u2214
lines.text: I was only strangling her... I've killed hundreds of women. It doesn't mean a thing.  Pootchkie, you're over-reacting. This is our night. It's what we've lied for... cheated for... murdered for. She's just a plaything, a trifle... You're the only woman who's ever meant anything to me. I adore you. I worship you. I want to make you my bride.

lines.speaker: u2216
lines.text: He'll never make it.

lines.speaker: u2213
lines.text: Think positive.

lines.speaker: u2218
lines.text: Stay away!

lines.speaker: u2214
lines.text: Or you'll what? CAN ME?

lines.speaker: u2220
lines.text: He's turned into a completely normal person!

lines.speaker: u2215
lines.text: Normal. What's normal? Does normal exist? And if it did, how would we know it?

lines.speaker: u2220
lines.text: Yes, Obie-wan.

lines.speaker: u2217
lines.text: Hey... he's gone.

lines.speaker: u2218
lines.text: Here you go.

lines.speaker: u2220
lines.text: Ow.

lines.speaker: u2218
lines.text: Maybe you guys ought to forget this Superhero stuff and join Kiwanis or something.

lines.speaker: u2220
lines.text: Oh, Mother, I'm sorry. I know how much you wanted me to be a doctor or a lawyer with a family -- but it's just not who I am!

lines.speaker: u2219
lines.text: But... the silverware?

lines.speaker: u2220
lines.text: I use it... to fight evil.

lines.speaker: u2219
lines.text: Jeffrey... this is wonderful.

lines.speaker: u2220
lines.text: It is?

lines.speaker: u2219
lines.text: I always knew that you were special.

lines.speaker: u2220
lines.text: You did?

lines.speaker: u2219
lines.text: Ever since you were a little boy...  Come with me.

lines.speaker: u2221
lines.text: Where am I going?

lines.speaker: u2220
lines.text: Through there!

lines.speaker: u2221
lines.text: Right.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: You can always tell at a glance whether retreating infantry are being pursed by cavalry, because they hurry along and keep turning around and looking back.  When they are retreating before infantry, they merely trudge along, head down.

lines.speaker: u2224
lines.text: Fascinating!  Tell me, leaving aside the question of grand strategy, for the moment, what would you say is the single most difficult tactical skill to master?

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: Without a doubt, to estimate the enemy's strength on the battlefield. This is something that is only acquired by experience and instinct. At Jena, there were as many opinions about strength of the enemy as there were generals present.  Murat said there were 50,000, preparing to attack.  Berthier said there were no more than 25,000, about to withdraw. "Berthier sees only what is in the open," Murat said.  "But don't forget there is a second force hidden in the forest."  And so it would always go, each of them would judge things according to his own ability, character and state of mind, at the moment.

lines.speaker: u2224
lines.text: Ah, my dear Napoleon, sometimes I feel that I am not really an Emperor as you are.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: What do you mean?

lines.speaker: u2224
lines.text: I know absolutely nothing of war -- and I am still totally dependent upon my generals.

lines.speaker: u2225
lines.text: I don't have to tell you of our latest difficulties.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: Things are quite serious, I should say.

lines.speaker: u2225
lines.text: We expect an attack on the Convention tomorrow morning, at daybreak, and I have been placed in charge of its defense.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: What do you have in mind?

lines.speaker: u2225
lines.text: To be perfectly honest, I haven't the vaguest idea.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: Are you serious?

lines.speaker: u2225
lines.text: I don't even know whether a defense is possible.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: What forces do you have at your disposal?

lines.speaker: u2225
lines.text: About 5,000 troops.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: Cavalry?

lines.speaker: u2225
lines.text: The 21st Dragoons, about two or three-hundred troopers.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: Any cannon?

lines.speaker: u2225
lines.text: There are none here.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: Where are they?

lines.speaker: u2225
lines.text: Well, I believe there are at least 30 guns at Sablons.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: You could have them here by daybreak.

lines.speaker: u2225
lines.text: Is this enough to oppose 40,000 men?

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: Properly arranged, yes.

lines.speaker: u2225
lines.text: These are odds of 8 to 1.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: The numbers are not particularly relevant.  You are not up against soldiers -- this is a mob, and they will run as soon as things become sufficiently unpleasant.

lines.speaker: u2225
lines.text: Would you be prepared to handle this for me?

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: Are you proposing to transfer command to me?

lines.speaker: u2225
lines.text: In every practical sense, yes, but, officially, of course, I would have to retain command.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: Fair enough.

lines.speaker: u2225
lines.text: I must be honest with you.  I first approached three generals more senior than yourself, and they all very prudently sent excuses.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: I'm not insulted.

lines.speaker: u2225
lines.text: You realize what is at stake?

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: Our lives, the revolution, my career?

lines.speaker: u2225
lines.text: Look, let me be completely open with you, I have a carriage and an escort waiting for me, and I have a great deal of money outside of France. Unless we stand a very good chance of carrying this off, I am prepared to call it quits right now.

lines.speaker: u2226
lines.text: But, sire, Your Majesty would lay Paris open to being sacked.  The enemy is outside the gates with more than 120,000 men.  Besides this, I left the city under the terms of a treaty and I am forbidden to reenter Paris.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: A treaty?  Don't be ridiculous. What treaty is this?  Who made it? Who has been giving orders?

lines.speaker: u2226
lines.text: I don't know the details of the treaty, sire, Marshal Mortier sent me word of its having been agreed to, and he said that I was to take the army and make for Fontainebleau.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: But who made this treaty?

lines.speaker: u2226
lines.text: I believe it was arranged by Marshals Mortier and Marmont.  I must explain to you that we have had no orders all day.  Each marshal has been keeping his own position.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: Who sent my wife and son out of Paris?

lines.speaker: u2226
lines.text: I don't know, sire.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: And where is Joseph?

lines.speaker: u2226
lines.text: I don't know what has happened to Prince Joseph.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: What cowardice!  What treason! Joseph has ruined everything.  How could they all lose their heads. They knew I was coming up fast. Victory was just within grasp. Come, come, turn your troops around, General Belliard.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: Who is there?

lines.speaker: u2227
lines.text: Bertrand, sire.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: I have just had the most vivid... dream... about Josephine.

lines.speaker: u2227
lines.text: Yes, sire?

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: She was sitting there... and it was as if I had last seen her only the night before... She hadn't changed -- she was still the same -- still completely devoted to me... and she told me we were going to see each other again and, never again, leave each other... She has promised me. Did you see her?

lines.speaker: u2227
lines.text: No, sire... I was asleep.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: I wanted to kiss her, but she didn't want to kiss me... She slipped away, the moment I wanted to take her in my arms.

lines.speaker: u2228
lines.text: This dispatch has just arrived from Aboukir, marked highest priority, for General Bonaparte's eyes only.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: Let me see it.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: Then, you have my thanks, Captain Charles, for safely escorting Madame Bonaparte to Milan, and you may consider your assignment completed.

lines.speaker: u2230
lines.text: Thank you, sir.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: You will return to Paris tomorrow and you will carry my compliments and thanks to General Le Clerc for assigning such an excellent officer to carry out a responsibility which has meant so much to myself and to Madame Bonaparte.

lines.speaker: u2230
lines.text: Thank you, sir.  I will do that.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: You may go, Captain Charles.

lines.speaker: u2231
lines.text: Just a minute, General.  Listen, don't let them fool you with all their grand la-de-da.  They've all made their money from the war -- mostly from crooked war contracts. They say Citizen Barras has put away millions.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: I see...

lines.speaker: u2232
lines.text: Hello there, Picart.

lines.speaker: u2247
lines.text: Ah, Didier -- you are alive.

lines.speaker: u2232
lines.text: Why are you carrying the dog?

lines.speaker: u2247
lines.text: His paws are frozen and he cannot walk.

lines.speaker: u2232
lines.text: When you eat him, may I have some?

lines.speaker: u2247
lines.text: My God -- don't you recognize Mouton -- our regimental dog?  I would rather eat Cossack.

lines.speaker: u2233
lines.text: The Emperor has decided to marry your Archduchess, Marie-Louise.

lines.speaker: u2249
lines.text: What is that?

lines.speaker: u2233
lines.text: Earlier this afternoon, the Emperor refused the hand of the Grand Duchess Anna, of Russia, and, as I'm sure you can appreciate, he is quite able to change his mind again.  For the Emperor, to choose a wife, is only a matter of minutes.

lines.speaker: u2249
lines.text: But this is not a matter which can be settled tonight, surely?

lines.speaker: u2233
lines.text: No one can say how the Emperor's thoughts work, Ambassador, and unless we move quickly, he might change his mind again.

lines.speaker: u2249
lines.text: But, my dear Duroc, how can I act without guidance from Vienna?  I haven't the slightest idea of how the Emperor Francis might feel about this.

lines.speaker: u2233
lines.text: May I suggest that we can prepare and sign the agreement, between ourselves, subject to the approval of the two Emperors.  Believe me, my dear friend, your Archduchess, Marie-Louis, may very well hold, in her hands, the future of our two countries.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: Good morning, Citizen de Beauharnais.

lines.speaker: u2234
lines.text: Good morning, sir.  Are you General Bonaparte?

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: I am, Citizen.  Is your mother Madame Josephine de Beauharnais?

lines.speaker: u2234
lines.text: Yes, sir.  Are you acquainted with her?

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: I have met her.  What is your business with me?

lines.speaker: u2234
lines.text: I believe you issued an order that all citizens of Paris must hand over any weapons that they have in their possession.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: That is correct.

lines.speaker: u2234
lines.text: This morning, a Lieutenant and three soldiers came to our house and asked if we had weapons.  I explained we had only my late father's sword, which, in fact, was not a weapon but only a keepsake of memory.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: A sword is a weapon whatever else you might wish to use it for.

lines.speaker: u2234
lines.text: I told the Lieutenant my late father was General Alexander de Beauharnais, and asked if there was any consideration that might be given to his memory.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: And he sent you to me?

lines.speaker: u2234
lines.text: He said no one had the authority to rescind the order except you.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: Does your mother know you have come?

lines.speaker: u2234
lines.text: No, sir.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: Well, then, you have a lot of initiative, my young friend.

lines.speaker: u2234
lines.text: My father's sword means more to me than any other possession I have.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: You realize, of course, that thousands of swords have been collected.  How do you expect me to find yours?

lines.speaker: u2235
lines.text: No -- not as a rule.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: Ah, well, that is the first rule of warfare.  You must wear long-sleeved and long-legged underwear.  You can never conjure up brilliancies with a cold bottom.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: What's your name?

lines.speaker: u2237
lines.text: Lisette.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: Only Lisette?

lines.speaker: u2237
lines.text: Lisette La Croix.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: That's a very nice name.  Where are you from?

lines.speaker: u2237
lines.text: Please, sir, come into bed or I shall die of a chill.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: Oh, yes... of course.

lines.speaker: u2238
lines.text: Will you use the troops?

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: Only as a last resort.  What are the Councils doing now?

lines.speaker: u2239
lines.text: Oh -- I didn't tell you... I've seen Dr. Corvisart, and he was very reassuring and encouraging.  He has had excellent results with the waters of Plombiers, and he thinks it would be a good idea for me to spend a few weeks there. Apparently, he sent Madame Le Floch there last year, and she gave birth to twins.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: Indeed -- well, you may tell Dr. Corvisart, I should be entirely satisfied with half her success.

lines.speaker: u2240
lines.text: I wanted to kill him but Joseph convinced me it would be a mistake. He said people would say you hadn't the courage to deal with it yourself.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: And was it so widely known that Joseph had reason for such concern?

lines.speaker: u2240
lines.text: I believe so.  I believe Madame Bonaparte was not discreet, in Paris.

lines.speaker: u2241
lines.text: Good day, monsieur.  Do you think it is possible for you to tell your driver to stop ringing that bell?

lines.speaker: u2248
lines.text: My regrets, my dear Major, but I believe you have been blocking the road.

lines.speaker: u2241
lines.text: Are you trying to provoke me, monsieur?

lines.speaker: u2248
lines.text: No, Major, I merely wish to state that your vehicle appears to be somewhat slower and heavier than mine, and point out that, if you would be kind enough to pull over to one side of the road, I could pass you and be on my way.

lines.speaker: u2241
lines.text: May I inform you, monsieur, that I am Major Fidon, official courier to the court of the Emperor Napoleon, on my way to our Embassy at St. Petersburg and, in accordance with the rules of the road, no one may overtake or pass me.

lines.speaker: u2248
lines.text: Before you quote the rules of the road to me, Major, may I point out to you that you are not in France now, but that you are a guest in Russia.

lines.speaker: u2241
lines.text: If I have given you any cause to be insulted, monsieur, may I offer you immediate satisfaction?

lines.speaker: u2248
lines.text: If you wish to put things on that basis, then I will say good day to you, monsieur.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: Do you know the joke about the two Swiss boys who go to a bordello for the first time?

lines.speaker: u2242
lines.text: No.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: Well, two nice little Swiss boys, who are virgins, decide they will save up their money and go to a bordello.

lines.speaker: u2245
lines.text: On January 1st, 1814, France itself was invaded.  Now, with a small army of raw recruits, Napoleon would have to face the powerful combination of England, Russia, Prussia and Austria, operating against him together, for the first time.  The balance of numbers had tilted irretrievably against him.

lines.speaker: u2244
lines.text: A year ago, the whole of Europe was marching alongside of us.  Today, the whole of Europe is marching against us.

lines.speaker: u2252
lines.text: Okay, I know what I want this time.

lines.speaker: u2256
lines.text: Anything you need.

lines.speaker: u2252
lines.text: Yo' cousin, Craig.  Hook us up.

lines.speaker: u2256
lines.text: That's it?

lines.speaker: u2252
lines.text: Just tell him to come over here and talk to me.

lines.speaker: u2256
lines.text: And I can go free?

lines.speaker: u2252
lines.text: Go, fo' I change my mind.

lines.speaker: u2262
lines.text: Why for?  Them boys are real player haters.

lines.speaker: u2253
lines.text: It's a long story.  Right now we gotta do somethin'.

lines.speaker: u2256
lines.text: I can't give you your damn money back on this.

lines.speaker: u2254
lines.text: Bullshit!  I'll go postal in this mothafucka!

lines.speaker: u2256
lines.text: Well, you gonna have to go postal then.

lines.speaker: u2260
lines.text: Tape his mouth shut.

lines.speaker: u2256
lines.text: Joker, a man like yourself can do a lot for this community.  By letting us go, you can improve black and brown relations.

lines.speaker: u2257
lines.text: Hey, how you get out of here.

lines.speaker: u2259
lines.text: I don't know.

lines.speaker: u2261
lines.text: Hey, what's going on?

lines.speaker: u2260
lines.text: Nothing.  What you want?

lines.speaker: u2261
lines.text: Are you going to take me to see Mom?

lines.speaker: u2260
lines.text: Take your car.

lines.speaker: u2261
lines.text: 'Take your car?'

lines.speaker: u2260
lines.text: Yeah, and hurry up.

lines.speaker: u2263
lines.text: Well, we better hit the road, too. Craig, get your stuff.

lines.speaker: u2267
lines.text: Well, Craig, you're welcome anytime.

lines.speaker: u2266
lines.text: Elroy, what happen?

lines.speaker: u2267
lines.text: I threw my back, again.

lines.speaker: u2266
lines.text: Aw, no lovin' tonight?

lines.speaker: u2267
lines.text: Naw, baby, no lovin' tonight.

lines.speaker: u2266
lines.text: Come on, baby, let's go in the house.

lines.speaker: u2267
lines.text: For what?  We ain't gonna have no house after the auction tomorrow!

lines.speaker: u2268
lines.text: Aw, gee. I sent her on an errand.

lines.speaker: u2270
lines.text: You sent my assistant on an errand.

lines.speaker: u2268
lines.text: I've been a bad boy.

lines.speaker: u2271
lines.text: Look...I've... I've got a problem. A big problem...

lines.speaker: u2269
lines.text: Oh, yeah?

lines.speaker: u2270
lines.text: Good luck.

lines.speaker: u2271
lines.text: Same to you.

lines.speaker: u2271
lines.text: Thanks for the shine.

lines.speaker: u2272
lines.text: Thanks for the tip.

lines.speaker: u2276
lines.text: Goddamnit, you fuckin' bum, come here!

lines.speaker: u2272
lines.text: Gimme a dollar.

lines.speaker: u2276
lines.text: Fuck you!

lines.speaker: u2277
lines.text: Well, is it real? Do we know anything about it?

lines.speaker: u2273
lines.text: It looks real. I don't know anything about guns.

lines.speaker: u2277
lines.text: Could I see it?

lines.speaker: u2276
lines.text: Close your eyes.

lines.speaker: u2274
lines.text: Why?

lines.speaker: u2276
lines.text: I've got something for you.

lines.speaker: u2274
lines.text: A surprise?

lines.speaker: u2276
lines.text: You ask too many questions. You want the surprise or not?

lines.speaker: u2275
lines.text: Come Back.

lines.speaker: u2276
lines.text: Yeah.

lines.speaker: u2275
lines.text: Put her on.

lines.speaker: u2276
lines.text: What gives?

lines.speaker: u2275
lines.text: Just put her on.

lines.speaker: u2285
lines.text: He never told about the money.

lines.speaker: u2279
lines.text: No.

lines.speaker: u2285
lines.text: What do you figure he done with it?

lines.speaker: u2279
lines.text: He took the secret with him when I dropped him.

lines.speaker: u2280
lines.text: You got common sense. She ain't. When you grow up that money'll be yours. Now swear. "I will guard Pearl with my life..."

lines.speaker: u2287
lines.text: I will guard Pearl with my life...

lines.speaker: u2280
lines.text: ..."and I won't never tell about the money."

lines.speaker: u2287
lines.text: And I won't never tell about the money.

lines.speaker: u2287
lines.text: Uncle Birdie!

lines.speaker: u2281
lines.text: Don't!

lines.speaker: u2287
lines.text: Hide us Uncle Birdie! He's a-comin' with his knife!

lines.speaker: u2290
lines.text: Where's Ruby?

lines.speaker: u2282
lines.text: She went.

lines.speaker: u2293
lines.text: And the Lord told that man --

lines.speaker: u2283
lines.text: Yes! Yes!

lines.speaker: u2293
lines.text: The Lord said, Take that money and throw it in the River!

lines.speaker: u2283
lines.text: Yes! Yes! Hallelujah!

lines.speaker: u2293
lines.text: Throw that money in the River! In THE RIVER!

lines.speaker: u2283
lines.text: IN THE RIIV-ER!

lines.speaker: u2284
lines.text: See ye got two more peeps to your brood.

lines.speaker: u2290
lines.text: Yeah, and ornerier than the rest.

lines.speaker: u2284
lines.text: How's your own boy, Miz Cooper?

lines.speaker: u2290
lines.text: Ain't heard from Ralph since last Christmas. Don't matter -- I've got a new crop.  I'm a strong tree with branches for many birds. I'm good for something in this old world and I know it, too! We know that she will rout the Devil.

lines.speaker: u2284
lines.text: Got a good buy in soap, Miz Cooper.

lines.speaker: u2290
lines.text: Don't need no soap. I'm boilin' down the fat from my hog.

lines.speaker: u2286
lines.text: Just look at you! Dust and filth from top to toe!

lines.speaker: u2286
lines.text: Want me to take 'em up and wash 'em good?

lines.speaker: u2289
lines.text: Thank you, no. Thank you, dear Icey. I'll tend to them. Thank you.

lines.speaker: u2287
lines.text: Nothin'.

lines.speaker: u2289
lines.text: Come to me, boy!

lines.speaker: u2289
lines.text: Just tell me now; where's the money hid?

lines.speaker: u2288
lines.text: But I swore. I promised John I wouldn't tell.

lines.speaker: u2289
lines.text: JOHN -- DOESN'T -- MATTER! Can't I get that through your head, you poor, silly, disgusting little wretch!

lines.speaker: u2290
lines.text: What do you want?

lines.speaker: u2289
lines.text: Them kids!

lines.speaker: u2290
lines.text: What are you after them for?

lines.speaker: u2289
lines.text: None of your business, Madam.

lines.speaker: u2290
lines.text: I'm givin' you to the count of three to get out that screen door; then I'm a-comin' across this kitchen shootin'!

lines.speaker: u2291
lines.text: Miz Cooper!

lines.speaker: u2290
lines.text: What?

lines.speaker: u2291
lines.text: The man! The man!

lines.speaker: u2297
lines.text: Oh my god, oh my god...

lines.speaker: u2294
lines.text: Get the kit!

lines.speaker: u2295
lines.text: Bring him out of what?

lines.speaker: u2299
lines.text: My dream.

lines.speaker: u2295
lines.text: How you plan to do that?

lines.speaker: u2299
lines.text: Just like I did the hat. Have a hold of the sucker when you wake me up.

lines.speaker: u2295
lines.text: Me?  Wait a minute, you can't bring someone out of a dream!

lines.speaker: u2299
lines.text: If I can't, then you all can relax, because it'll just be a simple case of me being nuts.

lines.speaker: u2295
lines.text: I can save you the trouble. You're nutty as a fruitcake. I love you anyway.

lines.speaker: u2299
lines.text: Good, then you won't mind cold-cocking this guy when I bring him out.

lines.speaker: u2295
lines.text: What!?

lines.speaker: u2299
lines.text: You heard me. I grab him in the dream -- you see me struggling so you wake me up. We both come out, you cold cock the fucker, and we got him. Clever, huh?

lines.speaker: u2295
lines.text: You crazy? Hit him with what?

lines.speaker: u2299
lines.text: You're a jock. You must have a baseball bat or something. Come to my window at midnight. And meanwhile...

lines.speaker: u2295
lines.text: Meanwhile...?

lines.speaker: u2299
lines.text: Meanwhile whatever you do don't fall asleep. Midnight.

lines.speaker: u2298
lines.text: Maybe god's punishing us all...

lines.speaker: u2296
lines.text: Keep your head -- this is a fucking flesh and blood killer we're talking about.

lines.speaker: u2298
lines.text: Like Rod Lane?

lines.speaker: u2299
lines.text: Feeling better?

lines.speaker: u2297
lines.text: They say you've bottomed out when you can't remember the night before.  No more drinking, Baby, suddenly I just don't feel like it any more.

lines.speaker: u2302
lines.text: What you dream?

lines.speaker: u2299
lines.text: I dreamed about this guy in a dirty red and yellow sweater; I dream in color, y'know; he walked into the room I was in, right, right through the wall, like it was smoke or something, and just stared at me. Sort of... obscenely. Then he walked out through the wall on the other side. Like he'd just come to check me out...

lines.speaker: u2302
lines.text: When did you have a nightmare?

lines.speaker: u2301
lines.text: Guys can have nightmares too, y'know. You ain't got a corner on the fucking market or something.

lines.speaker: u2314
lines.text: From Leon.

lines.speaker: u2303
lines.text: From Leon!... How is he?... Come, tell us... open it... tell us... how is he?

lines.speaker: u2314
lines.text: No, I left everything in Paris. I just happened to be wearing this.

lines.speaker: u2304
lines.text: Tell me... what else did you have?

lines.speaker: u2314
lines.text: Well, a hat...

lines.speaker: u2304
lines.text: What was it like?

lines.speaker: u2314
lines.text: It was very silly.... I would be ashamed to wear it here.

lines.speaker: u2304
lines.text: As beautiful as that? What else? Come, tell me.

lines.speaker: u2314
lines.text: An evening gown.

lines.speaker: u2304
lines.text: Evening gown?

lines.speaker: u2314
lines.text: A dress you wear in the evening.

lines.speaker: u2304
lines.text: What do you wear in the morning?

lines.speaker: u2314
lines.text: When you get up you put on a negligee, and then you change to a morning frock.

lines.speaker: u2304
lines.text: You mean to tell me you wear a different dress for different times of the day?

lines.speaker: u2314
lines.text: Yes.

lines.speaker: u2304
lines.text: Now, Ninotchka, you're exaggerating.

lines.speaker: u2314
lines.text: No, my dear, it is true. That's how they live in the other world. Here we dress to have our bodies covered... to keep warm....

lines.speaker: u2304
lines.text: And there?

lines.speaker: u2314
lines.text: Well, sometimes they're not completely covered but... they don't freeze.

lines.speaker: u2304
lines.text: They must have wonderful materials to make a thing like this so soft... something you don't even see.

lines.speaker: u2314
lines.text: You feel it, though.

lines.speaker: u2304
lines.text: Ninotchka, I wouldn't bring this up if we weren't such good friends.

lines.speaker: u2314
lines.text: What is it, Anna?

lines.speaker: u2304
lines.text: You know I told you that Pavlov and I are going to get married when he comes back from the maneuvers. Would it be asking too much...

lines.speaker: u2314
lines.text: You want this?

lines.speaker: u2304
lines.text: Just for the honeymoon.

lines.speaker: u2314
lines.text: You can have it for good. It is my wedding present.

lines.speaker: u2312
lines.text: Boys, boys... don't forget Russia is your mother country. Three sons walking out all at once... that's too much for any mother.

lines.speaker: u2305
lines.text: Well, if your mother turns against you, you have to look for someone to adopt you.

lines.speaker: u2312
lines.text: What time have you, Gaston?

lines.speaker: u2306
lines.text: Eight forty-two, sir.

lines.speaker: u2312
lines.text: I guess it is eight forty-two.

lines.speaker: u2306
lines.text: You seem to be a bit nervous, sir.

lines.speaker: u2312
lines.text: I am, Gaston.

lines.speaker: u2306
lines.text: If you will forgive me, ever since you met that Bolshevik lady I've noticed a distinct change in you, sir.

lines.speaker: u2312
lines.text: Have you?

lines.speaker: u2306
lines.text: Decidedly. Yesterday I was greatly amazed when I came from the market and found that you had made your bed, sir.

lines.speaker: u2312
lines.text: And Gaston, I was happier all day long. I felt I'd contributed something.

lines.speaker: u2306
lines.text: Well, sir, if you should do it again, which I hope you won't, please remember the order. Counterpane, blanket, blanket, sheet, sheet.

lines.speaker: u2312
lines.text: Ah, there's something poetic about the simple processes of labor. Counterpane, blanket, blanket, sheet, sheet... it should be set to music!

lines.speaker: u2306
lines.text: May I add, sir, that it was with great amazement that I found a copy of Karl Marx's Capital on your night table. That is a socialistic volume which I refuse to so much as dust, sir. I view with alarm, sir, the influence over you of this Bolshevik lady.

lines.speaker: u2312
lines.text: I can't follow you, Gaston, isn't it about time that you realized the unfairness of your position? You being my servant? Wouldn't you like to stand on an equal footing with me?

lines.speaker: u2306
lines.text: No, sir.

lines.speaker: u2312
lines.text: Isn't there any revolt in you? Sometimes when I order you around don't you feel like kicking me in the pants?

lines.speaker: u2306
lines.text: No, sir.

lines.speaker: u2312
lines.text: Oh, you're a reactionary! Don't you look forward to the day when you can come in here and stand square on your two feet and say, "Hey, you, d'Algout! from now on it's going to be share and share alike"?

lines.speaker: u2306
lines.text: Emphatically not, sir. The prospect terrifies me. Now, don't misunderstand me, sir, I don't resent your not paying me for the past two months, but the thought that I should split my bank account with you... that you should take half of my life's savings... that is really too much for me.

lines.speaker: u2320
lines.text: General, would you mind making my excuses at our table? I'll be back in a few moments.

lines.speaker: u2307
lines.text: Certainly.

lines.speaker: u2308
lines.text: Is this satisfactory?

lines.speaker: u2320
lines.text: Thank you, Louis.

lines.speaker: u2309
lines.text: A Special Envoy is coming from Moscow. He'll occupy the Royal Suite. Move our things to the smallest room you've got.

lines.speaker: u2313
lines.text: Yes, monsieur.

lines.speaker: u2309
lines.text: Right away... instantly!

lines.speaker: u2310
lines.text: ...and Kopalski.

lines.speaker: u2314
lines.text: Don't make it difficult for me. This is no more a pleasure trip for me than it is for you.

lines.speaker: u2311
lines.text: We'll leave these papers here for your further consideration. Au revoir, madame.

lines.speaker: u2314
lines.text: Au revoir.

lines.speaker: u2312
lines.text: Now, please, Swana.

lines.speaker: u2320
lines.text: Count d'Algout was for several years my personal representative and if it is necessary to sign any affidavit for him I'll be delighted.

lines.speaker: u2312
lines.text: That does it, Swana.  Now you mustn't miss your appointment with your hair-dresser.

lines.speaker: u2320
lines.text: Just in case they don't give you your visa to Russia I want you to know that I have signed a contract for my memoirs and rented a lovely little ch창teau in the Touraine, and if you feel the need of a change...

lines.speaker: u2312
lines.text: Thank you, Swana. You are very gracious.

lines.speaker: u2321
lines.text: Where to, madame?

lines.speaker: u2314
lines.text: Can you recommend a restaurant?

lines.speaker: u2321
lines.text: Well, there's Pruniers if you care for seafood. If you want to lunch in the Bois, there's...

lines.speaker: u2314
lines.text: Where do you eat?

lines.speaker: u2321
lines.text: At P챔re Mathieu's.

lines.speaker: u2314
lines.text: Where is that?

lines.speaker: u2321
lines.text: It's just a place for workmen.

lines.speaker: u2314
lines.text: Where is it?

lines.speaker: u2321
lines.text: Eight blocks down in the Rue de Poivrel.

lines.speaker: u2318
lines.text: I am sorry... I have to leave.

lines.speaker: u2320
lines.text: Thank you so much, my friend. I will get in touch with you.

lines.speaker: u2340
lines.text: For Christ's sake, it soils my mother's memory.  Do you think I want the whole goddamn world to see my mother like this?  Raising a dirty mouth!

lines.speaker: u2322
lines.text: But sir, we'll have to start over from the beginning.  We don't have the staff to ...

lines.text: How's the job coming, Bob?

lines.speaker: u2323
lines.text: Frankly, sir, it stinks.  I have no access.  I'm lucky Helms lets me have a staff.

lines.speaker: u2340
lines.text: We'll see about that ...

lines.speaker: u2340

lines.speaker: u2323
lines.text: That's Helms.  He's "sang froid," a world-class poker player.

lines.text: Yeah?  Well, I own the fucking casino.

lines.speaker: u2332

lines.speaker: u2332
lines.text: John, sooner or later -- sooner, I think -- you are going to learn the lesson that has been learned by everyone who has ever gotten close to Richard Nixon.  That he's the darkness reaching out for the darkness.  And eventually, it's either you or him. Look at the landscape of his life and you'll see a boneyard.

lines.speaker: u2340
lines.text: I don't know, I don't know ... I just know we've made too many enemies.

lines.text: Executive privilege will make it look like we're covering up.

lines.speaker: u2340
lines.text: We are covering up!  For some petty, stupid shit.  There are things I can say -- when other people say them, they'd be lies. But when I say them nobody believes me anyway ...

lines.speaker: u2340
lines.text: ... they smelled the blood on me this time, Al.  I got soft.  You know ... that rusty, metallic smell ...

lines.speaker: u2340
lines.text: It came over from Vietnam, you know.

lines.speaker: u2326
lines.text: Sir?

lines.speaker: u2340
lines.text: That smell.  I mean, everybody suffered so much, their sons killed. They need to sacrifice something, y'know, appease the gods of war -- Mars, Jupiter.  I am that blood, General.  I am that sacrifice, in the highest place of all ... All leaders must finally be sacrificed.

lines.speaker: u2340
lines.text: ... There can be no whitewash at the White House ... two wrongs do not make a right.  I love America.  God bless America and God bless each and every one of you.

lines.speaker: u2327
lines.text: Sir ... six bodies.

lines.text: It's a gift, Richard.  This law school is a gift from your brother.

lines.speaker: u2328

lines.speaker: u2340

lines.speaker: u2340
lines.text: No.

lines.speaker: u2330
lines.text: Black Irishman.  Very moving. "Turning and turning in the widening gyre / The falcon cannot hear the falconer / Things fall apart, the center cannot hold / Mere anarchy is loosed upon the world / And everywhere the ceremony of innocence is drowned / The best lack all conviction, while the worst are full of passionate intensity" ... But it ends so beautifully ominous -- "What rough beast, its hours come round at last / Slouches toward Bethlehem to be born?" ... Yes, this country stands at such a juncture.

lines.speaker: u2340
lines.text: This damned tie ... Will you help me, Edgar?  Churchill used to say to me, "If you want your own history written properly, you must write it yourself."  All right, Edgar, but just don't let it come back to haunt me.

lines.speaker: u2331

lines.speaker: u2337
lines.text: Fung pi!   I've only managed to change a few things around the city of Beijing.  I want to know your secret.

lines.speaker: u2337

lines.speaker: u2337

lines.speaker: u2339

lines.speaker: u2340

lines.speaker: u2343
lines.text: Well, that's wonderful.  So get me this "crisis" thing, Dick; I'll be glad to take a look at it.

Anyway, first one I don't remember so well but it was about meetin' him in town somewheres and he give me some money and I think I lost it. The second one, it was like we was both back in older times and I was on horseback goin' through the mountains of a night.

lines.speaker: u2351

lines.speaker: u2352

lines.text: No... she just wanted something outta life. Anything. And with Del, she wasn't getting nothing. That's her husband, Del. I'm sorry about what happened and all, but that's the way I feel about all of this...
